funder.name: Department of Science and Technology, Government of Kerala

abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The mango fruit fly, <jats:italic>Ceratitis</jats:italic> (<jats:italic>Ceratalaspis</jats:italic>) <jats:italic>cosyra</jats:italic>, is a major agricultural pest affecting mango production in sub‐Saharan Africa. Morphological differences between <jats:italic>C. cosyra</jats:italic> and five closely related <jats:italic>Ceratitis</jats:italic> (<jats:italic>Ceratalaspis</jats:italic>) species (<jats:italic>C. discussa</jats:italic>,<jats:italic> C. pallidula, C. quinaria</jats:italic>,<jats:italic> C. silvestrii</jats:italic>,<jats:italic> C. striatella</jats:italic>) are subtle, so that their identification often requires specialized expertise. A previous study based on nuclear molecular markers (microsatellites) showed cryptic genetic variation within <jats:italic>C. cosyra</jats:italic> with separate microsatellite genotypic clusters also occurring in sympatry. This study aimed at verifying whether DNA barcoding can (a) separate <jats:italic>C. cosyra</jats:italic> from morphologically similar <jats:italic>Ceratitis</jats:italic> (<jats:italic>Ceratalaspis</jats:italic>) species and (b) resolve the cryptic genetic variation previously observed within <jats:italic>C. cosyra</jats:italic>. A subset of 62 <jats:italic>C. cosyra</jats:italic> specimens previously genotyped at 16 microsatellite loci was subjected to DNA barcoding. This data set was integrated with 130 DNA barcodes of <jats:italic>C. cosyra, C. discussa</jats:italic>,<jats:italic> C. quinaria</jats:italic>,<jats:italic> C. silvestrii</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>C. striatella</jats:italic>. Neighbor Joining, maximum likelihood and Bayesian tree reconstructions confirmed the presence of two main <jats:italic>C. cosyra</jats:italic> genotypic groups and resolved well‐supported groups corresponding to <jats:italic>C. discussa, C. pallidula, C. striatella</jats:italic> and to <jats:italic>C. quinaria</jats:italic>/<jats:italic>C. silvestrii</jats:italic>. The analysis of morphological characters did not show consistent morphological differences between the two groups of <jats:italic>C. cosyra</jats:italic> and called into question the morphological characters currently implemented in the identification of <jats:italic>C. striatella</jats:italic>. These results further support the hypothesis of cryptic speciation within the mango fruit fly and suggest that DNA barcoding represents a suitable complementary tool for the problematic diagnosis of <jats:italic>C. cosyra</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>C. striatella</jats:italic>.</jats:p>
title: The complex case of Ceratitis cosyra (Diptera: Tephritidae) and relatives. A DNA barcoding perspective
